Historians look back at this event and agree: it not only represented a tipping point for mill workers in Lawrence and New England, but for the labor movement across the entire US.
In #Lawrence, it was women who helped lead the 1912 ‚ÄúBread and Roses‚Äù Strike to fight for a fair wage, safer working conditions, and a brighter future for their families.

In #Lowell, a half-century before better-known movements for workers' rights in the US, it was women working in Lowell mills that organized, mobilized, & went on strike for better wages & working conditions. Their efforts created the first union of working women in US history.
This #LaborDay I am I am thinking of our own history right here in Lowell and Lawrence. In the early 1900‚Äôs cities like Lawrence and Lowell helped forge the modern labor movement. #MA3
